thread.title: England train ahead of Italy Six Nations clash with help of Jonny Wilkinson - and Eddie Jones' dog
thread.title_full: England train ahead of Italy Six Nations clash with help of Jonny Wilkinson - and Eddie Jones' dog

author: Callum Davis
title: England train ahead of Italy Six Nations clash with help of Jonny Wilkinson - and Eddie Jones' dog
text:
England train ahead of Italy Six Nations clash with help of Jonny Wilkinson - and Eddie Jones' dog England's training session was a star-studded affair on Wednesday afternoon Credit: REX Callum Davis 22 February 2017 • 7:24pm 
E ddie Jones brought his dog Annie to England training on Wednesday afternoon as the Six Nations champions looked to maintain their quest for back-to-back Grand Slams. 
As revealed in an exclusive interview with lock Courtney Lawes , Eddie Jones' training sessions are often notoriously brutal, but never before have they featured live animals. 
After putting his team through the ringer just three days after their comeback win over Wales in Cardiff , Jones sprung another surprise on his players by bringing his dog Annie to training. Owen Farrell attempts to stop Annie from stealing his kicking tee Credit: Getty Images Eddie Jones chases his dog, Annie Credit: Getty Images 
T he diminutive dog was seen running around the training pitch as England players watched on in amusement. 
At one point England centre Owen Farrell had to shoo away Jones' dog after she tried to steal his kicking tee. 
Eddie Jones' pooch was not the only special guest to put in an appearance at England's midweek training session. Former Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew watches England train with Richard Hill Credit: REX 
2003 World Cup-winning fly-half Jonny Wilkinson was on hand to offer kicking tips, while former Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew took advantage of his time away from management to watch the Six Nations favourites train. 
P ardew, who was sacked by Crystal Palace at the start of this season, was joined on the sidelines by England team manager and England World Cup winner, Richard Hill. 
Wilkinson has worked with the England team on an ad-hoc basis and Eddie Jones has previously described the former fly-half as the last truly world-class player to represent England. Jonny Wilkinson coaches Mike Brown on his kicking out of hand Credit: Getty Images Jonny Wilkinson shares a joke with full-back Mike Brown Credit: REX 
“If you look at the record of English rugby since 2003, there’s only been one world class player produced and that’s Jonny Wilkinson. 
“There hasn’t been the desire from the players to push themselves and be great. 
“To do that you have to work that little bit smarter and work that little bit harder.” Billy Vunipola watches on at Pennyhill Park Credit: REX 
E ngland welcome Italy to Twickenham on Sunday where they hope to extend their extraordinary winning record. 
Billy Vunipola is on target to return for England's Six Nations finale against Ireland, a fixture that could see them win the Grand Slam and break New Zealand's record for consecutive wins. 
Billy's brother, Mako, could play a part in England's matchday squad on Sunday after proving his fitness in two appearances for Saracens. Follow Telegraph Sport
